attachments.title: How to Handle your Python packaging in Lambda with Serverless plugins
attachments.text: Handling Python dependencies in your Lambda functions can be a pain. Here's how I handle Python packaging with Serverless for dev/prod parity.
attachments.fallback: serverless: How to Handle your Python packaging in Lambda with Serverless plugins

text: ah no, this seems even simpler: <https://docs.aws.amazon.com/pinpoint/latest/developerguide/tutorials-importing-data-create-python-package.html> without having to use PIP and docker

attachments.title: Step 3: Create a package that contains the required Python libraries - Amazon Pinpoint
attachments.text: The solution that's documented in this tutorial uses several libraries that aren't included with the standard Python package that Lambda uses. To use these libraries, you first have to download them on your computer. Next, you create a .zip archive that contains all of the libraries. Finally, you upload this archive in Lambda so that you can call the libraries from your functions.
attachments.fallback: Step 3: Create a package that contains the required Python libraries - Amazon Pinpoint

text: in general if you don't need c++-based stuff like numpy you can just pack them in a zip and use them as a layer, for a lot of other things like numpy there are pre-built layers you can just add.. in the end I was happy to skip docker :stuck_out_tongue:

text: Hello everyone - another basic question: what markets provide decent volatility whilst working without delay (which I guess is all pre-play?) ? So far I'm seeing some volatility in the last few minutes leading up to horse races

elements.text: Hello everyone - another basic question: what markets provide decent volatility whilst working without delay (which I guess is all pre-play?) ? So far I'm seeing some volatility in the last few minutes leading up to horse races

text: Horse racing pre-event is the obvious answer

elements.text: Horse racing pre-event is the obvious answer

text: some volatility compared to football for instance which has pretty much no volatility pre-inplay

elements.text: some volatility compared to football for instance which has pretty much no volatility pre-inplay

text: ah nice, okay that confirms my suspicion. Thanks, Mo

elements.text: ah nice, okay that confirms my suspicion. Thanks, Mo

text: I realise that this might be a super open-ended question but do you know what drives pr-event volatility in horse racing?

elements.text: I realise that this might be a super open-ended question but do you know what drives pr-event volatility in horse racing?

text: vis-a-vis all other events

elements.text: vis-a-vis all other events

text: My total guess is that horse racing markets take longer to reach efficiency

elements.text: My total guess is that horse racing markets take longer to reach efficiency

text: There is also quite a bit of new information just before the event, like how the horse looks in the paddock, how it goes into the stalls and so on. How indicative those things really are I couldn't say but people set a lot of store by them.

elements.text: There is also quite a bit of new information just before the event, like how the horse looks in the paddock, how it goes into the stalls and so on. How indicative those things really are I couldn't say but people set a lot of store by them.

text: id guess horse racing market would reach faster efficiency (not most of the action happening in the last 5) if there was derivative type instruments such as futures ( with an option type call) which wouldn't require the massive exposures for long periods of time on the lay side

text: <@U01GL10CHL6> has joined the channel

Hey all, I had an idea of making a (desktop) app that displays live odds and game stats from many bookmakers. The app will be free, but the catch is that only if many people use it, will it work. It will work by scraping the sites from the _users_ computers and sharing the data between everyone.

So, wanted to ask, would you be interested in this, or is it a waste of time?

It should look something like this <https://i.imgur.com/LMNaO4O.png|https://i.imgur.com/LMNaO4O.png>

Just to clarify, I'm not aiming at the "traditional" bookmakers (Bet365, Unibet, Betfair, etc...), I want to list the ones you never see on those "aggregating" sites (1xBit, Sportsbet, Stake, FortuneJack, Bodog...)

elements.text: Hey all, I had an idea of making a (desktop) app that displays live odds and game stats from many bookmakers. The app will be free, but the catch is that only if many people use it, will it work. It will work by scraping the sites from the _users_ computers and sharing the data between everyone.

So, wanted to ask, would you be interested in this, or is it a waste of time?

It should look something like this
https://i.imgur.com/LMNaO4O.png

Just to clarify, I'm not aiming at the "traditional" bookmakers (Bet365, Unibet, Betfair, etc...), I want to list the ones you never see on those "aggregating" sites (1xBit, Sportsbet, Stake, FortuneJack, Bodog...)

text: Straight off I think you are breaking regulations with the bookmakers' IP

elements.text: Straight off I think you are breaking regulations with the bookmakers' IP

text: Republishing is likely to get you into hot water

elements.text: Republishing is likely to get you into hot water

text: Private use, since you have access to the sites, it pretty much OK

elements.text: Private use, since you have access to the sites, it pretty much OK

text: Beyond that, two questions immediately come to mind. 1) Is this an app that people would want? 2) What do you get out of it?

elements.text: Beyond that, two questions immediately come to mind. 1) Is this an app that people would want? 2) What do you get out of it?

text: 1. People who bet crypto will surely find this interesting. A single dashboard where they can follow all movements.

elements.text: 1. People who bet crypto will surely find this interesting. A single dashboard where they can follow all movements.

text: Some of these sites are pretty horrible to navigate, adding links from me app to them might increase the amounts betted on them as a result

elements.text: Some of these sites are pretty horrible to navigate, adding links from me app to them might increase the amounts betted on them as a result

text: 2. I’m not sure. There’s an obvious path of making money off it, but I don’t feel like doing premium features. I’ll have to think about it

elements.text: 2. I’m not sure. There’s an obvious path of making money off it, but I don’t feel like doing premium features. I’ll have to think about it

text: If you plan to make money from it I suspect you will have a problem with the IP of providing prices from other sites. The "dodgy" ones may not care, but the legit ones, like Sportsbet, certainly won't be amused

elements.text: If you plan to make money from it I suspect you will have a problem with the IP of providing prices from other sites. The "dodgy" ones may not care, but the legit ones, like Sportsbet, certainly won't be amused

text: The basic premise is that the price data isn't yours to republish (unless you have a commercial deal with the agency)

elements.text: The basic premise is that the price data isn't yours to republish (unless you have a commercial deal with the agency)

text: Think what would happen if you built a site and published the Betfair prices :wink:

elements.text: Think what would happen if you built a site and published the Betfair prices

text: So an <http://oddschecker.com|oddschecker.com> for less mainstream bookmakers? I think there is good value in that
